He knows that this transformation is what brought forth the very essence of those Names in us, just as we know that the transformations of states are the rulings of those Names. The Name of the state from which I transformed and to which I transformed is my Name, by which I transform, just as I was transformed by it.

By the Name the Compassionate, the Merciful (الرءوف الرحيم), the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was compassionate and merciful to the believers. By the Name the Believer (المؤمن), he was a believer. By the Name the Guardian (المهيمن), he was a guardian. He made us witnesses over one another and over ourselves.

By the Names the Patient (الصبور) and the Grateful (الشكور), the affliction of the wind driving the ships in the sea was a Sign <<لِكُلِّ صَبَّارٍ>> (for every patient one) due to the terrifying and dreadful matter it contained, and <<شَكُورٍ>> (grateful one) due to the joy and blessing of reaching the desired destination quickly. I witnessed this through my own direct experience (ذوقا): we sailed by strong wind from mid-morning until sunset, a distance of twenty days' journey, in waves like mountains. How much more would we have covered if the sea had been calm and the wind behind us? But God willed to show us the Signs of every patient and grateful person.

There is no Name by which He named Himself but that He named us by it. By these Names, we transform in our states, and by them, we transform others. Whoever knows these Signs has been transported by the Real through His Names, showing him His Signs, so that he becomes hearing and seeing: hearing what the Real informs him of through definitions by the specific tongue (اللسان الخاص)—which is the revealed Word He attributes to Himself—and by the general tongue (اللسان العام)—which is what the entire World speaks, whatever they speak.

Indeed, we heard what the Real recounted to us of the speech of the Jews concerning Him, and we heard it from the Jews. Thus, we heard it by the general and specific tongues. He recounted what they uttered, for it is not within the capacity of the created being to utter without being made to utter. When he utters, he utters—so understand. He recounted through him, about them, from Him.

When his portion of the ascension through the Names is complete, and he knows the Signs that the Names of God granted him in that ascension, he returns to re-compose his essence (ذاته) with a composition different from the first, due to the knowledge he acquired, which he did not possess when he dissolved. He continues to pass through the categories of the World, taking from each world what he left with it, and thus he is re-composed in his essence. He continues to appear in stage after stage until he reaches the Earth and wakes up among his family. No one knows what has occurred in his secret until he speaks, and they hear from him a tongue (لسانا) other than the one they knew. If one of them asks him, "What is this?" he replies, "God transported me and showed me His Signs as He willed."

The listeners say to him, "We did not miss you. You lie in what you claim." And the jurist (الفقيه) among them says, "This man claims prophecy, or he has suffered a defect in his intellect. He is either a heretic (زنديق) who must be killed, or an imbecile with whom we have no discourse." So, some mock him, others take heed, and others believe his saying. The matter becomes a point of contention in the World.

The jurist is heedless of the saying of the Exalted: <<سَنُرِيهِمْ آياتِنا في الْآفاقِ وفي أَنْفُسِهِمْ>> (We shall show them Our Signs in the horizons and in themselves), and He did not exclude one group from another. Whoever God shows something of these Signs in this manner we have described, let him mention what he saw, but not the method (الطريقة), for he will be believed, and his words will be considered. Denial only occurs if he claims the method.

### [Seeing the Signs and the Transformations of States in the Entire World are Signs]

Know that there is no difference between the World and the possessor of this method and attribute in terms of the ascension, because the seeing of the Signs and the transformations of states are Signs (آيات) in the entire World, and they are within them, yet they do not perceive it. This category of people does not surpass the rest of the veiled creation (الخلق المحجوبين) except by what God inspires in their secret: looking with their intellect and thought, or preparing the polish of the mirror of their heart, so that these Signs are unveiled (كشف) to them through witnessing (شهود), direct experience (ذوقا), and finding (وجودا).

The World denies the very essence of what they are in and upon. Were it not for his mentioning the method by which he attained the knowledge of these things, no one would deny him. All people—and I exclude none of them—strike similitudes (الأمثال) for God, and they have agreed upon this, and none of them denies the other, yet God says: <<فَلا تَضْرِبُوا لِلَّهِ الْأَمْثالَ>> (So do not strike similitudes for Allah). They are in blindness concerning this verse.

As for the saints of God (أولياء الله), they do not strike similitudes for God, for it is God Who strikes similitudes for people, due to His knowledge of their significance, because God knows, and we do not know. The saint witnesses the similitudes that God strikes, and in that witnessing, he sees the very essence of the commonality (الجامع) between the similitude and that for which the similitude was struck. It is its very essence from the perspective of that commonality, but it is not its very essence from the perspective of being a similitude.

The saint does not strike similitudes for God; rather, he knows what God struck similitudes for, such as His saying, the Exalted: <<الله نُورُ السَّماواتِ والْأَرْضِ مَثَلُ نُورِهِ>> (Allah is the Light of the heavens and the earth. The similitude of His Light)—meaning the description of His Light—<<كَمِشْكاةٍ فِيها مِصْباحٌ الْمِصْباحُ في زُجاجَةٍ الزُّجاجَةُ كَأَنَّها كَوْكَبٌ دُرِّيٌّ يُوقَدُ من شَجَرَةٍ مُبارَكَةٍ زَيْتُونَةٍ لا شَرْقِيَّةٍ ولا غَرْبِيَّةٍ يَكادُ زَيْتُها يُضِي‏ءُ ولَوْ لَمْ تَمْسَسْهُ نارٌ نُورٌ عَلى‏ نُورٍ يَهْدِي الله لِنُورِهِ من يَشاءُ>> (is as a niche wherein is a lamp. The lamp is in a glass, the glass as it were a brilliant star, lit from a blessed tree, an olive, neither of the east nor of the west, whose oil would almost glow even if no fire touched it. Light upon Light. Allah guides to His Light whom He wills). This is by the similitude He struck for His servants concerning this Light, by the lamp for His Light, by which He guides whom He wills. <<ويَضْرِبُ الله الْأَمْثالَ لِلنَّاسِ والله بِكُلِّ شَيْءٍ عَلِيمٌ>> (And Allah strikes similitudes for mankind, and Allah is Knower of all things).

This is a specific lamp; it is not every lamp. It should not be said that the Light of God is like the lamp because the lamp reveals everything upon which its light spreads for the one who has sight. Such a statement is incorrect, for God did not mention the conditions, attributes, and descriptions of this lamp, which is the object of the similitude, in vain. Such a lamp is the one by which the similitude is struck, for God knows how to strike similitudes. He said that He only strikes similitudes for mankind, and He forbade us from striking similitudes for God, for God knows, and we do not know.

If we strike similitudes, let us look: if God has struck a similitude for mankind concerning that matter, let us stop there—that is the Divine etiquette (الأدب الإلهي). If we do not find a similitude struck by God concerning that, then let us strike a similitude for the people who only know that through a struck similitude. If we are fair, we should not strike it for God, for God knows it. You should strive for correctness in striking that similitude if you are a person of thought and consideration. But if you are a person of unveiling (كشف) and witnessing (شهود), do not strive, for you are upon clear evidence from your Lord. Do not intend what you are in, but rather present it as you witnessed it, just as one recounts the similitude God struck for Himself. This is the state of the saints of God concerning the striking of similitudes.

As He said concerning the disagreement of people regarding the number of the People of the Cave (أصحاب الكهف), it was "guessing at the unseen" (رجما بالغيب) because they did not witness them. Therefore, He used the future tense: <<سَيَقُولُونَ ثَلاثَةٌ>> (They will say, "Three," and so on). Then He said: <<قُلْ رَبِّي أَعْلَمُ بِعِدَّتِهِمْ ما يَعْلَمُهُمْ>> (Say, "My Lord is most knowing of their number; none knows them) <<إِلَّا قَلِيلٌ>> (except a few)—either those who witnessed them and were not overcome by illusion, or those whom God informed of their number.

The Exalted also said: <<ما يَكُونُ من نَجْوى‏ ثَلاثَةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ رابِعُهُمْ ولا خَمْسَةٍ إِلَّا هُوَ سادِسُهُمْ>> (There is no secret counsel of three but that He is their fourth, nor of five but that He is their sixth). This is by way of allusion in combining the two verses. However, as He said, He is the fourth of three, not the third of three, because one is only called the fourth of four in the same genus (الجنس الواحد) and in similitudes. If the similitude is negated, He is not called the fifth of five if He is with them. Rather, He is called the fifth of four or the sixth of five. Do you not see that when the dog was not of the human species, they said, <<سَبْعَةٌ وثامِنُهُمْ كَلْبُهُمْ>> (Seven, and the eighth of them is their dog), and they did not say, "Eight, the eighth of them is their dog"? Understand this, and you will be correct, God willing.

> So do not strike a similitude for the Lord of the Cosmos / From His cosmos.
> For none resembles Him / Exalted is He in His Essence (ذاته) and elevated.
> I did not strike a similitude for Him / Though all people have done so.
> So do not strike a similitude for Him / And be among the party of those who understand.

When God desired to transport me (أسرى بي) to show me His Signs in His Names (أسمائه) from my own names (من أسمائي)—which is the portion of our inheritance from the Isra'—He removed me from my place and ascended me upon the Buraq of my possibility (براق إمكاني). He cast me into my elements (أركاني). I did not see my Earth element (أرضى) accompany me. I was told, "The Original Father (الوالد الأصلي), whom God created from dust (تراب), took it."

When I separated from the element of Water (ركن الماء), I lost a part of myself. I was told, "You are created from despised water (ماءٍ مَهِينٍ), and its humiliation disgraced it, so it clung to the dust. That is why you separated from it." Thus, two parts were diminished from me.

When I reached the element of Air (ركن الهواء), the desires (الأهواء) changed upon me. The Air said to me, "What was in you from me shall not depart from me, for it should not exceed its measure nor stretch its leg beyond its carpet. I have a claim against you for what your putrefaction (تعفينك) changed in me, for without it, you would not have been molded (مسنونا). I am inherently pure, but corrupted by the company of those who neighbor me." When my company and proximity corrupted it, it was said of it, "molded clay" (حمأ مسنون). So its corruption returned to it, for it is the one described, and it is the one that changed me in the nostrils of the people of smell (أهل الشم) among the people of fragrances. I asked it, "Why do I leave it with you?" It said, "Until this corruption that it acquired from your putrefaction and the proximity of your clay and water departs from it." So I left it with it.

When I reached the element of Fire (ركن النار), it was said, "The proud one (الفخار) has come." It was asked, "Has he been sent for?" It said, "Yes." It was asked, "And who is with him?" It said, "Gabriel, the Compeller (الجبر). He is compelled in his journey and the separation of his constitution (بنيته)." It said to me, "A part of me is in his origination (نشأته), and I will not leave it with him, since he has reached the Presence (الحضرة) where my dominion, power, and effective disposal manifest."

I penetrated the first heaven, and nothing remained of my bodily constitution (نشأتي البدنية) upon which I could rely or look. I greeted my father (Adam). He asked me about my soil. I told him that the Earth took its part from me, and at that point, I departed from it and from the water with my clay. He said to me, "O my son, this is what happened to it with your father. Whoever seeks his right has not transgressed, especially since you are departing from it and do not know whether you will return to it or not, for the Exalted says: <<إِذا شاءَ أَنْشَرَهُ>> (When He wills, He resurrects him), and no one knows what is in the Will of the Real unless the Real informs him of it."

I turned, and behold, I was before him, and on his right were the souls of his children—my very essence (عيني). I said to him, "This is me." He laughed. I said to him, "So I am before you and on your right?" He said, "Yes. This is how I saw myself before the Real when He stretched out His Hand. I saw myself and my children in that Hand, and I saw myself before Him." I asked him, "What was in the other, closed Hand?" He said, "The World (العالم)." I said to him, "So the Right Hand of the Real decrees the designation of felicity (السعادة)?" He said, "Yes, it decrees felicity." I said to him, "So the Real has distinguished for us between the People of the Right and the People of the Left." He said to me, "O my son, that is your father's right and left. Do you not see the souls of my children on my right and on my left? But both Hands of my Lord are a blessed Right Hand (يمين مباركة). He created me and my children in His Right Hand, and everything other than us in the other Divine Hand." I said, "Then we shall not be wretched?" He said, "If the Wrath (الغضب) were permanent, wretchedness would be permanent. But felicity is permanent, even if the dwelling differs, for God places in every abode that which constitutes the bliss of the inhabitants of that abode. Both abodes must be inhabited. The Wrath ends on the Day of the Greater Presentation (العرض الأكبر), and the command is given to establish the limits (الحدود), and they are established. When they are established, the Wrath departs, for the Message removes it. It is the very establishment of the limits upon the one who incurred Wrath. Nothing remains but contentment (الرضاء), which is the Mercy (الرحمة) that <<وَسِعَتْ كُلَّ شَيْئٍ>> (encompasses all things)."

When the limits are concluded, the ruling belongs to the general Mercy (الرحمة العامة) in its universality. My father Adam granted me this knowledge, of which I was not aware. This was an immediate Divine good tidings for me in the life of this world. The Resurrection ends in time, as God said, <<خَمْسِينَ أَلْفَ سَنَةٍ>> (fifty thousand years). This is the duration for the establishment of the limits. After the expiration of this period, the ruling returns to the All-Merciful (الرحمن الرحيم). The All-Merciful possesses the Beautiful Names (الأسماء الحسنى), and they are beautiful for whomever they are directed to by the ruling. The Merciful (الرحيم), by His Mercy, takes vengeance upon the Wrath (الغضب), being severe in His grip upon it, humiliating it, and preventing it by His Reality. Thus, the ruling remains in the conflict of the Names (تعارض الأسماء) in relation to the relationships, and creation is immersed in Mercy. The ruling of the Names remains in their conflict, not in us—so understand, for this is a strange and subtle knowledge (علم غريب دقيق) that people do not perceive; rather, they are in blindness concerning it. There is none among them but that if you said to him, "Would you be content for yourself to be ruled by the Name that displeases you?" he would say, "No," and he would assign the ruling of that displeasing Name to someone else. This person is the most ignorant of creation, and even more ignorant of the Real.

This witnessing benefited me by showing that the rulings of the Names remain in the Names, not in us. They are relationships (نسب) that oppose each other by their realities and never combine. God spreads His Mercy over His servants wherever they are. All Existence (الوجود) is Mercy.

Then I journeyed from him after he prayed for me. I descended to Jesus, peace be upon him, in the second heaven. I found with him his cousin, John (Yahya), peace be upon him. This represented animal life (الحياة الحيوانية). If John was his cousin, he would be a spirit (روح). Since animal life is inseparable from the spirit, I found John with Jesus, the Spirit of God (روح الله), because the spirit is undoubtedly alive, but not every living thing is a spirit.

I greeted them both. I asked Jesus, "By what did you surpass us so that God named you the Spirit attributed to God?" He said, "Do you not see the one who bestowed me upon my mother?" I understood what he meant. He said to me, "Were it not for this, I would not have revived the dead." I said to him, "We have seen those who revived the dead who did not have an origination like yours." He said, "Those who revived the dead only did so to the extent of what they inherited from me. They did not stand in my place in that, just as I do not stand in the place of the one who bestowed me (meaning Gabriel) in reviving the dead. For the one who bestowed me does not step on a place but that place comes alive by his step. I am not like that. Rather, our portion is to establish the forms by stepping only, and the Universal Spirit (الروح الكل) takes charge of the spirits of those forms. What the Spirit who bestowed me steps upon grants life in the form that the step manifested." Know that.

Then I turned my face to John, peace be upon him, and said to him, "I was informed that you will slaughter Death (الموت) when God brings it on the Day of Resurrection, placing it between Paradise and the Fire so that both groups may see it and know that it is Death in the form of a speckled ram." He said, "Yes, and that is only fitting for me, for I am *Yahya* (He Lives), and my opposite cannot remain with me. That is the Abode of Life (دار الحيوان), so Death must be removed, and there is none to remove it but me." I said to him, "You spoke the truth in what you alluded to."

"But there are many *Yahyā* in the World," I said. He replied, "But I have the rank of priority (الأولية) in this Name. By me, everyone who lives, whether preceding or succeeding, lives. And God did not make for me a namesake before. Every *Yahya* is a follower of mine. By my manifestation, they have no ruling." He alerted me to something I did not possess. I said, "May God reward you well, O possessor of inheritance."

I said, "Praise be to God Who gathered you both in one heaven—I mean Jesus, the Spirit of God, and John, peace be upon them—so that I may ask you one question and receive the answer in the presence of both of you. For you were both singled out by the greeting of the Real (سلام الحق). It was said of Jesus that he said in the cradle: <<والسَّلامُ عَلَيَّ يَوْمَ وُلِدْتُ ويَوْمَ أَمُوتُ ويَوْمَ أُبْعَثُ حَيًّا>> (And peace be upon me the day I was born, and the day I die, and the day I am raised alive). And it was said of John: <<وسَلامٌ عَلَيْهِ يَوْمَ وُلِدَ ويَوْمَ يَمُوتُ ويَوْمَ يُبْعَثُ حَيًّا>> (And peace be upon him the day he was born, and the day he dies, and the day he is raised alive). Jesus informed of the peace of the Real upon himself, and the Real informed of His peace upon John. Which station is more complete?"

He said to me, "Are you not one of the People of the Quran?" I said, "Yes, I am one of the People of the Quran." He said, "Look at what the Real combined between me and my cousin. Did God not say concerning me: <<ونَبِيًّا من الصَّالِحِينَ>> (And a Prophet among the righteous), specifying me in the indefinite form (النكرة)?" I said, "Yes." He said, "Did He not say concerning my cousin Jesus: <<إِنَّهُ من الصَّالِحِينَ>> (Indeed, he is among the righteous), specifying him in the indefinite form as He did me? Then he said, 'Since Jesus' speech in the cradle was proof of my aunt's innocence from what was attributed to her, only he himself spoke on behalf of God, saying: <<والسَّلامُ عَلَيَّ>> (And peace be upon me)—meaning from God.'" I said, "You spoke the truth."

I said, "But he greeted with the definite article (التعريف), and the peace of the Real upon you is with the indefinite article (التنكير), and the indefinite is more general." He said to me, "It is not the definition of an essence (عين), but the definition of a genus. There is no difference between it with the definite article and without it. We and he are equal in peace, and likewise in righteousness. And righteousness came to us through good tidings, and to Jesus through the angels." I said to him, "You have benefited me; may God benefit you."

Then I asked him, "Why were you *Hasur* (حصورا - abstinent)?" He said, "That was the effect of my father's spiritual resolve (همة) when he saw the state of Mary the Virgin (مريم البتول)—the one cut off from men—when he entered the sanctuary and was pleased by her state. He prayed to God to grant him a son like her. So I came forth abstinent, cut off from women. It is not an attribute of perfection; rather, it was the effect of a spiritual resolve, for in procreation (الإنتاج) is the very essence of perfection."

I said to him, "Is there no procreation in the marriage of Paradise?" He said, "Do not say that. There is procreation, and it must be. Its birth is a soul (نفس) that emerges from the wife upon the completion of intercourse, for the emission is wind (ريح), just as it is water in this world. That wind emerges in the form of the union that occurred between the spouses. Some of us witness that, and some do not, just as is the case in this world: a world of the unseen for those absent from it, and a world of witnessing for those who witness it." I said to him, "You have benefited me; may God benefit you with His blessings of knowledge of Him."

Then I said to him, "Is this your heaven?" He said to me, "No. I move between Jesus and Aaron. I am with this one and with that one, and likewise with Joseph and Idris, peace be upon them." I said to him, "Why did you single out Aaron over the other Prophets?" He said to me, "For the sanctity of kinship (حرمة النسب). I only came to Jesus because he is my cousin, so I visit him in his heaven. And I come to Aaron because my aunt is his sister, both in religion and kinship."

I said, "But he is not her brother, for there is a long time and a world between them." He said to me, "His saying: <<وإِلى‏ ثَمُودَ أَخاهُمْ صالِحاً>> (And to Thamud, their brother Salih)—what is this brotherhood? Do you think he was the brother of Thamud by his father and mother? He was their brother, for the tribe was named Thamud, and Salih was from the lineage of Thamud, so he is undoubtedly their brother. Then the brotherhood of religion came after that. Do you not see that when the People of the Thicket (أصحاب الأيكة) were not from Midian, and Shu'ayb was from Midian, He said concerning Shu'ayb, 'the brother of Midian': <<وإِلى‏ مَدْيَنَ أَخاهُمْ شُعَيْباً>> (And to Midian, their brother Shu'ayb). But when the People of the Thicket were mentioned, He said: <<إِذْ قالَ لَهُمْ شُعَيْبٌ>> (When Shu'ayb said to them), and did not say 'their brother,' because they were not from Midian, and Shu'ayb was from Midian. So my visit to them is a connection of kinship, and I am closer to Jesus than I am to Aaron."

Then I ascended to the third heaven, to Joseph, peace be upon him. After greeting him, and he returned the greeting, made things easy, and welcomed me, I said, "O Joseph, why did you not answer the caller when he called you, when the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said of himself that if he had been afflicted with what you were afflicted with and called, he would have answered the caller and not remained in prison until the answer came from the king concerning what the women said?"

He said to me, "Between direct experience (الذوق) and assumption (الفرض) is the distance between heaven and earth. There is a great difference between assuming a matter and experiencing it yourself. If what was attributed to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was attributed to me, he would have sought the verification of his innocence in his absence, for that is more indicative of his innocence than his presence. Since he was a mercy (رحمة), he belonged to the world of spaciousness (السعة), and prison is confinement (ضيق). If this state comes to one whose state is this, he hastens to relief. This is an assumption. Speech based on a hypothetical assumption is not like speech based on direct experience. Do you not see that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, only mentioned that in the context of attributing perfection to me for what I endured of the slander against me? He said that out of etiquette (أدبا) toward me, because I was older than him in time, just as he said concerning Abraham: 'We are more entitled to doubt than Abraham in what Abraham doubted.' And he said concerning Lot: 'May God have mercy on my brother Lot. He indeed sought refuge in a strong support (رُكْنٍ شَدِيدٍ).' Do you think he accused him of lying? God forbid! For the strong support that Lot intended was the tribe, and the strong support that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned was God. This is an alert to you not to apply yourself in a matter in which you have no direct experience (ذوق) in the same way as one who has experienced it. Do not say, 'If I were in the place of so-and-so, I would not have said such-and-such.' No, by God! If what afflicted him afflicted you, you would say what he said, for the stronger state governs the weaker state."

"In Joseph, who is a Messenger of God, two states converged: the state of imprisonment and the state of being slandered. The Messenger seeks to establish in the mind of the one he is sent to what will make him accept the call of his Lord to Him. What was attributed to him is known by everyone not to occur from one who comes with a call to them. Therefore, he had to seek acquittal from that in their presence so that they would believe in what he brought from his Lord. He did not attend that session himself so that suspicion would not enter the hearts of those present due to his presence. There is a great difference between one who is present in such a situation and one who is not."

"Since the woman did not betray Joseph in his absence when she acquitted him and attributed the solicitation to herself, she knew that Joseph had not betrayed the Aziz in his family, and she knew that he was more deserving of this description than she was in his regard. She did not acquit herself, but said: <<إِنَّ النَّفْسَ لَأَمَّارَةٌ بِالسُّوءِ>> (Indeed, the soul is ever inciting to evil). It was part of Joseph's spiritual chivalry (فتوة) that he remained in prison after the king called him out. Only the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, knew the measure of that, where he said of himself, 'I would have answered the caller,' praising Joseph."

I said to him, "What does the shared expression in God's informing about you—<<ولَقَدْ هَمَّتْ به وهَمَّ بِها>> (She desired him, and he desired her)—indicate in the language concerning the oneness of the meaning?" He said, "That is why I told the king, through his messenger, to ask about the women and the nature of the matter. The woman only mentioned that she solicited him, and she did not mention that he solicited her. Thus, what was imagined of that was removed. Since God did not name the matter in expressing that, nor specify a state in it."

I said to him, "There must be a shared meaning in the language." He said, "You are right. She desired me to overcome me (لتقهرني) to achieve what she wanted from me, and I desired her to overcome her (لأقهرها) in repelling that. The shared aspect occurred in the seeking of conquest (القهر) from me and from her. That is why He said: <<ولَقَدْ هَمَّتْ به>> (And she desired him)—meaning in the very essence of what he desired—and that is nothing but conquest in what each one desired from the other. The proof of this is her saying: <<الْآنَ حَصْحَصَ الْحَقُّ أَنَا راوَدْتُهُ عَنْ نَفْسِهِ>> (Now the truth has become manifest. I solicited him for myself). Nowhere in the Surah is it mentioned that he solicited her for himself. God showed him the proof (البرهان) when he intended conquest in repelling her from what she desired from him. The proof he saw was to defend himself with gentle speech (القول اللين), as He said to Moses and Aaron: <<فَقُولا لَهُ قَوْلًا لَيِّناً>> (So speak to him with gentle speech)—meaning, do not be harsh with her or insult her, for she is a woman described by weakness in every state." I said to him, "You have benefited me; may God benefit you."

Then I bade him farewell and departed to Idris, peace be upon him. I greeted him, and he returned the greeting, made things easy, and welcomed me, saying, "Welcome, O Muhammadan inheritor." I said to him, "How was the matter ambiguous to you, according to what reached us, so that you did not know the matter of the Flood (الطوفان) with certainty, while the Prophet stands with what is revealed to him?" He said, "<<وأَرْسَلْناهُ إِلى‏ مِائَةِ أَلْفٍ أَوْ يَزِيدُونَ>> (And We sent him to a hundred thousand or more). This is what was revealed to me."

I said to him, "It reached me from you that you affirm the breaking of the norm (الخرق)." He said, "Were it not for the breaking of the norm, I would not have been raised to a high place (مكانا عليا)." I said, "Where is your station from your place?" He said, "The outward is the title of the inward."

I said, "It reached me that you only sought Monotheism (التوحيد) from your people, nothing else." He said, "And what did they do? I was a Prophet calling to the *word* of Monotheism (كلمة التوحيد), not to Monotheism itself, for no one denies Monotheism." I said, "This is strange."

Then I said, "O Establisher of the Ruling, independent reasoning (الاجتهاد) in subsidiary matters (الفروع) is permissible for us, and I am the tongue of the scholars of the time." He said, "And in the fundamentals (الأصول) it is permissible, for God is too majestic to burden a soul beyond its capacity." I said, "But disagreement concerning the Real and the sayings about Him have multiplied." He said, "It must be so, for the matter follows the temperament (المزاج)." I said, "But I saw that you, the company of Prophets, did not disagree concerning Him." He said, "That is because we did not speak from speculation (نظر); rather, we spoke from a single source of revelation (إل واحد). Whoever knows the realities knows that the agreement of all the Prophets on a single saying concerning God is equivalent to the saying of a single speculative thinker."

I said, "Is the matter in itself as you were told, even though the proofs of the intellects deem some of what you brought concerning it impossible?" He said, "The matter is as we were told, and as those who spoke about it said, for God is present in the saying of every speaker. That is why we only called people to..."

The word of Unity (Tawhid) does not lead to Unity itself. And whoever speaks concerning the Real (al-Haqq) from his own perspective has not spoken of something forbidden, for what He legislated for His servants is the Unity of the Level (tawhid al-martaba), and there is nothing there except those who affirm it. I said: "Then the polytheists (al-mushrikūn)?" He said: "They only took what was established (al-waḍ‘), so in that they lied in their establishments and took them as a means of proximity (qurba), yet they did not assign them the rank of the Singular (Aḥadiyya) possessor of that Level."

I said: "I saw in my vision a person performing the circumambulation (ṭawāf) who informed me that he was one of my ancestors and named himself to me. I asked him about the time of his death, and he told me: 'Forty thousand years ago.' I asked him about Adam, given what is established among us regarding the historical duration of his life." He said: "Which Adam are you asking about? The nearest Adam?" He said: "He spoke truly. I am a Prophet of God, and I do not know a total duration for the World (al-‘ālam) at which we might stop, except that, generally speaking, He has never ceased to be the Creator, and He will not cease to be the World and the Hereafter. The appointed times (ājāl) are in the created being (al-makhlūq) by the termination of durations, not in the act of Creation (al-khalq). Creation is renewed with every breath. What we have been taught, we know, and <<وَلَا يُحِيطُونَ بِشَيْءٍ مِنْ عِلْمِهِ إِلَّا بِمَا شَاءَ>> (They encompass nothing of His knowledge except what He wills)."

I said to him: "Then how much remains until the Hour appears?" He said: <<اقْتَرَبَ لِلنَّاسِ حِسَابُهُمْ وَهُمْ فِي غَفْلَةٍ مُعْرِضُونَ>> (The reckoning of mankind has drawn near, while they are in heedlessness, turning away). I said: "Then inform me of a condition for its approach." He said: "The existence of Adam is one of the conditions of the Hour." I said: "Was there an abode before this world (Dunya) other than it?" He said: "The abode of Existence (dār al-Wujūd) is one. The abode was not the world except through you, and the Hereafter was not distinguished from it except through you. The matter concerning bodies is merely existences (akwān), transformations (istiḥālāt), coming, and going, which has never ceased and will never cease." I said: "What is there beyond that?" He said: "We do not know, and what we do not know, we do not know."

I said: "Then where is the error (al-khaṭā’) from the correctness (al-ṣawāb)?" He said: "Error is a relative matter (amr iḍāfī), and Correctness is the Origin (al-Aṣl). Whoever knows God and knows the World knows that Correctness is the enduring Origin (al-Aṣl al-mustaṣḥab) that never ceases, and that Error arises from the opposition of two perspectives. Opposition is necessary, so error is necessary. Thus, whoever affirms error affirms correctness, and whoever denies error speaks correctly and makes error part of correctness."

I said: "From which Attribute did the World originate?" He said: "From Generosity (al-Jūd)." I said: "I heard some Shaykhs say this." He said: "What he said is true." I said: "And what will be the outcome after our transition from the Day of Presentation?" He said: "The Mercy of Allah encompasses all things." I said: "Which thing?" He said: "The two things (al-shay’iyyatan)." For the one He causes to subsist (al-bāqī), He causes to subsist by His Mercy, and the one He brings into existence (al-mūjid), He brings into existence by His Mercy. Then he said: "The loci of accidents (maḥāll al-‘awāriḍ) are fixed in their existence, and the accidents are replaced upon them by similarities and opposites." I said: "What is the Greatest Matter?" He said: "The one who knows Him is greater." Then I bade him farewell and departed.

I descended to Harun (Aaron), peace be upon him, and found that Yahya (John) had preceded me to him. I said to him: "I did not see you on my path. Is there another path?" He said: "Every person has a path that none but he travels." I said: "Then where are these paths?" He said: "They come into being with the occurrence of the journey (sulūk)."

I greeted Harun, peace be upon him, and he returned the greeting, welcomed me, and said: "Welcome to the Perfected Heir (al-wārith al-mukammal)." I said: "You are the Caliph of the Caliph, despite being a Messenger and a Prophet." He said: "As for me, I am a Prophet by virtue of the Origin (al-Aṣl), and I only received the Message (Risāla) through the request of my brother. I was inspired with what I was upon."

I said: "O Harun, some Gnostics (al-‘ārifīn) claim that Existence (al-Wujūd) is annihilated for them (yan‘adim fī ḥaqqihim), so they see only God, and the World holds nothing for them to turn to alongside God. There is no doubt that they are at a lower Level (martaba) than the likes of you. Yet the Real informed us that you said to your brother in his anger: 'Do not let the enemies rejoice over me,' thereby granting them a status. This state contradicts the state of those Gnostics."

He said: "They spoke truly, for they did not exceed what their spiritual taste (dhawq) granted them. But look: Has that part of the World which vanished for them truly vanished?" I said: "No." He said: "Then their knowledge of the reality of the matter is deficient to the extent of what they missed. They perceive the non-existence of the World, so their knowledge of the Real is deficient to the extent of what was veiled from them of the World. For the entire World is the very essence of the Theophany (Tajallī) of the Real for one who knows the Real. <<فَأَيْنَ تَذْهَبُونَ إِنْ هُوَ إِلَّا ذِكْرٌ لِلْعَالَمِينَ>> (Then where are you going? It is nothing but a reminder to the worlds) concerning the reality of the matter."

> For perfection is nothing but its existence,
> So whoever misses it is not the Perfected one.

> O speaker of Annihilation (Fanā’), be patient,
> And gather the yield from the ear of grain.

> Do not rely upon what has passed away,
> And do not sell the ready cash for the deferred.

> Do not let the soul follow its desires,
> And do not mix the Real (al-Haqq) with the False (al-Bāṭil).

Then I bade him farewell and descended to Musa (Moses), peace be upon him. I greeted him, and he returned the greeting, welcomed me, and made things easy. I thanked him for what he did on our behalf concerning the revision of the prescribed prayers that occurred between him and our Prophet Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. He said to me: "This is the benefit of the knowledge of Taste (dhawq)." For direct experience (al-mubāshara) has a state that cannot be grasped except through it.

I said: "You never ceased striving on behalf of others until all goodness became valid for you." He said: "A person’s striving on behalf of others is, in reality, striving for himself. That only increases the gratitude of others, and the grateful person is a rememberer of God (dhākir) through the praises most beloved to God. The striver has a connection to those praises, so the striver is a rememberer of God with his own tongue and the tongue of others."

God the Exalted said to Moses, peace be upon him: "O Moses, remember Me with a tongue with which you have not disobeyed Me."

Thus, He commanded him to remember Him with the tongue of others, commanding him to benevolence and generosity.

Then I said to him: "God chose you above mankind by His Message and His Speech, yet you asked for the Vision (Ru’ya), while the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, says: 'None of you shall see his Lord until he dies.'"

He said: "That is exactly what happened. When I asked Him for the Vision, He answered me, and I fell down unconscious (ṣa‘qan), and I saw Him, the Exalted, in my unconsciousness." I asked: "Death?" He said: "Death." I said: "The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, doubted your case when he found you on the Day of Resurrection, not knowing whether you had been recompensed by the unconsciousness of Mount Tur and thus would not be struck unconscious by the Trumpet of Unconsciousness, for the Trumpet of Unconsciousness does not encompass everyone." He said: "You spoke truly. God recompensed me with the unconsciousness of Mount Tur, so I did not see Him, the Exalted, until I died. Then I awoke, and I knew Whom I had seen. That is why I said: <<تُبْتُ إِلَيْكَ>> (I turn in repentance to You), for I only returned to Him."

I said: "You are among the scholars of God. What was the Vision of God for you when you asked for it?" He said: "It was an intellectually necessary obligation (wājiba wujūban ‘aqlīyan)." I said: "In what way were you distinguished above others?" He said: "I used to see Him, but I did not know that it was He. When the station changed for me and I saw Him, I knew Whom I had seen. When I awoke, I was not veiled, and His Vision accompanied me forever and ever. This is the difference between us and those who are veiled from the knowledge of what they see. When they die, they see the Real (al-Haqq), and the station distinguishes Him for them. If they were returned, they would say the same as we said."

I said: "If death were the station of His Vision, every dead person would see Him, yet God described them as being veiled from His Vision." He said: "Yes, they are veiled from the knowledge that it is He. If you intend to meet a person whom you do not know by sight, and you seek him by his name and your need for him, and you meet him and greet him, and he greets you among the group you met, but he does not introduce himself to you—you have seen him, yet you have not seen him. You remain seeking him while he is where you see him. Therefore, reliance is only upon Knowledge (al-‘Ilm). For this reason, we said that Knowledge is the very Essence (al-Dhāt) of the Real, for if it were not His very Essence, the object of reliance would be other than God, and there is no reliance except upon Knowledge."

I said to him: "God guided you to the mountain and mentioned concerning Himself that He disclosed Himself (tajallā) to the mountain." He said: "Nothing remains firm under His Theophany, so the state must change. The crushing (dakk) of the mountain was like the unconsciousness (ṣa‘q) for Moses." Moses says: "The One who crushed it struck me unconscious."

I said to him: "God took charge of teaching me, so I learned from Him according to what He granted me." He said: "This is how He acts with those who know Him. So take from Him, not from the Cosmos (al-Kawn). For you will only take according to your preparedness (isti‘dād). Do not let Him veil you from Him by means of the likes of us, for you will only learn from Him through us what we learn from Him through His Theophany. We only give you from Him according to your preparedness, so there is no difference. Attribute yourself to Him, for we were only sent to call you to Him, not to call you to ourselves. This is a <<كَلِمَةٍ سَوَاءٍ بَيْنَنَا وَبَيْنَكُمْ أَلَّا نَعْبُدَ إِلَّا اللَّهَ وَلَا نُشْرِكَ بِهِ شَيْئًا وَلَا يَتَّخِذَ بَعْضُنَا بَعْضًا أَرْبَابًا مِنْ دُونِ اللَّهِ>> (a word common between us and you: that we worship none but Allah and associate nothing with Him and that none of us take others as lords besides Allah)."

I said: "Thus it came in the Qur’an." He said: "And thus it is." I said: "With what did you hear the Speech of God?" He said: "With my hearing." I said: "And what is your hearing?" He said: "He is it." I said: "Then in what were you distinguished?" He said: "By a Taste (dhawq) in that, which only its possessor knows." I said to him: "Is it the same for the people of Taste?" He said: "Yes, and the tastes are according to the Levels (marātib)."

Then I bade him farewell and departed.

I descended to Ibrahim the Intimate (al-Khalīl), peace be upon him. I greeted him, and he returned the greeting, welcomed me, and made things easy. I said: "O Father, why did you say: <<بَلْ فَعَلَهُ كَبِيرُهُمْ>> (Nay, their chief did it)?" He said: "Because they affirm the greatness (kibriyā’) of the Real (al-Haqq) over the deities they adopted." I said: "And your allusion with this saying?" He said: "You know it." I said: "I know that it is an allusion of initiation, and its predicate is omitted, indicated by your saying: <<بَلْ فَعَلَهُ كَبِيرُهُمْ هَذَا فَاسْأَلُوهُمْ>> (Nay, their chief did it, so ask them), establishing the argument against them from themselves." He said: "You have not added anything to the reality of the matter."

I said: "What is your view on the three lights (stars, moon, sun)? Was that based on belief?" He said: "No, rather it was for the purpose of instruction (ta‘rīf) to establish the argument against the people. Do you not see what the Real said concerning that: <<وَتِلْكَ حُجَّتُنَا آتَيْنَاهَا إِبْرَاهِيمَ عَلَى قَوْمِهِ>> (And that was Our argument which We gave to Abraham against his people)? The belief of the people concerning the deity was only that it was Nimrod son of Canaan. Those lights were not their deities, nor was Nimrod a god for them. Rather, they referred in their worship to what they had carved as deities, not to him. That is why, when Abraham said: <<رَبِّيَ الَّذِي يُحْيِي وَيُمِيتُ>> (My Lord is the one who gives life and causes death), Nimrod did not dare to attribute giving life and causing death to the deities he had established for them, lest he be exposed. So he said: <<أَنَا أُحْيِي وَأُمِيتُ>> (I give life and cause death), shifting the claim to himself, in order to exalt their deities in their eyes so that the attendees would not waver. When Abraham knew the deficiency of the attendees' understanding regarding what he had brought, had he detailed it and prolonged the session, he shifted to what was closer to their understanding. So he mentioned the matter of God bringing the sun from the East and his request that Nimrod bring it from the West, <<فَبُهِتَ الَّذِي كَفَرَ>> (and the one who disbelieved was confounded)."

I said to him: "This confounding was a miracle (i‘jāz) from God, that he was confounded in a matter about which he had a counter-argument, even if it was false. For if he had said it, he would have been told: 'The sun has always risen from the East, and you were not there,' and those older than him would have immediately contradicted him." He said: "What is the counter-argument?" I said: "He could say: 'We do not perform the matter according to your ruling, nor is wisdom invalidated for your sake.'" He said: "You spoke truly. So his confounding was a miracle from God, the Glorified, so that the attendees knew that Abraham, peace be upon him, was upon the Real (al-Haqq). And Nimrod was not able to claim divinity."

Then I saw the Visited House (al-Bayt al-Ma‘mūr), and behold, it was my heart (qalbī). And behold, the angels who enter it every day are the Theophany (Tajallī) of the Real, the Glorified, Who encompasses it within seventy thousand veils of light and darkness. He discloses Himself within them to the heart of His servant; if He were to disclose Himself without them, the splendors of His Face would burn the world of creation of that servant.

When I left it, I came to the Lote Tree of the Utmost Boundary (Sidrat al-Muntahā). I stood between its lower and upper branches, and the lights of deeds (anwār al-a‘māl) covered it, and the birds of the souls of the doers sang in its high branches. It was upon the formation of the human being. As for the four rivers, they are the four sciences of Divine Gift (ulūm al-wahb) that we mentioned in a treatise of ours called *The Levels of the Sciences of the Gift*.

Then I witnessed the couches of the carpets (rafārif) of the Gnostics, and the lights covered me until I became entirely light. I was clothed in a robe I had never seen the like of. I said: "My God, the signs (āyāt) are scattered." Upon this saying, the verse was revealed to me: <<قُلْ آمَنَّا بِاللَّهِ وَمَا أُنْزِلَ عَلَيْنَا وَمَا أُنْزِلَ عَلَى إِبْرَاهِيمَ وَإِسْمَاعِيلَ وَإِسْحَاقَ وَيَعْقُوبَ وَالْأَسْبَاطِ وَمَا أُوتِيَ مُوسَى وَعِيسَى وَالنَّبِيُّونَ مِنْ رَبِّهِمْ لَا نُفَرِّقُ بَيْنَ أَحَدٍ مِنْهُمْ وَنَحْنُ لَهُ مُسْلِمُونَ>> (Say, "We believe in Allah and what was revealed to us and what was revealed to Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac and Jacob and the Descendants and what was given to Moses and Jesus and the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and we are Muslims [submitting] to Him)."

In this verse, He gave me all the signs, made the matter easy for me, and made it the key to all knowledge. I knew that I was a compilation of those mentioned to me, and I received the glad tidings that I was of the Muhammadan Station (Maqām), among the heirs of the comprehensiveness (jam‘iyya) of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him. For he is the last Messenger and the last to whom revelation descends. God gave him the comprehensive words (Jawāmi‘ al-Kalim) and distinguished him with six things with which no Messenger of any nation was distinguished. His Message was universal due to the universality of its six directions. From whichever direction you come, you will find nothing but the light of Muhammad providing for you. No one has taken anything except from him, and no Messenger has informed except about him.

When this was granted to me, I said: "Enough for me! Enough for me!" It had filled my pillars, and my place could not contain me. By it, He removed my possibility (imkān) from me.

In this Ascent (Isrā’), I attained the meanings of all the Names (al-Asmā’), and I saw them returning to a single Named (musammā) and a single Essence (‘ayn). That Named was my object of Witnessing (mashhūdī), and that Essence was my Existence (wujūdī). My journey was only within Him, and my indication was only upon myself. From this, I knew that I am a pure servant (‘abd maḥḍ), having absolutely nothing of Lordship (Rubūbiyya) in me.

The treasures of this station were opened, and I saw within them the science of the singularity of honored servitude (aḥadiyyat ‘ubūdat al-tashrīf), which I had not seen before. I had only seen the comprehensiveness of servitude (jam‘iyyat al-‘ubūdiyya). I saw the science of the Unseen (al-Ghayb) with the eye of Witnessing (al-Shahāda). Where is the limit of the Unseen from the World? Everything returns to Witnessing for the servant. By the Unseen, I mean the Unseen of Existence (ghayb al-Wujūd)—that which is in Existence but is veiled from some eyes and insights. As for the Unseen of what is not existent, the key to that Unseen is known only to Him, the Exalted.

I saw in it the science of Proximity and Distance, from whom and about whom.

I saw in it the science of the treasures of increased knowledge (mazīd al-‘ulūm) and their descent upon the hearts of the Gnostics, and by whom it is realized, and who distributes it to the hearts, and what descends from it upon request and without request. If a person asks for increased knowledge, let him ask as God commanded His Prophet to ask, when He said to him: <<وَقُلْ رَبِّ زِدْنِي عِلْمًا>> (And say, "My Lord, increase me in knowledge"). He used an indefinite term (knowledge) and did not specify, thus making it general. Any knowledge that descends upon him falls under this request. For the descent upon request is a greater pleasure than the descent without request, as it involves the attainment of the desired object, the humility of need (iftiqār), and giving Lordship its due and Servitude its due. For the servant is commanded to give everything its due, just as God gave everything its creation. And in the knowledge that descends upon request, there is a loftiness of rank whose measure is known only to God.

I saw the science of confining the signs (āyāt) to hearing and sight—either Witnessing (shuhūd) or report (khabar).

I saw the Torah and the science of its distinction in that God wrote it with His Hand. I wondered at this: How did He write it with His Hand yet not preserve it from the alteration and distortion (taḥrīf) that the Jews, the companions of Moses, inflicted upon it? When I wondered at this, it was said to me in my secret: "Listen to the address, or rather, I see the Speaker and witness Him in the vastness of the Mercy in which I stand, and which has encompassed me." He said to me: "More wondrous than that is that He created Adam with His two Hands, yet He did not preserve him from disobedience or forgetfulness. And where is the rank of the Hand compared to the two Hands? So wonder at this! The two Hands were only directed toward his clay and his nature, and the whispering (waswasa) only came to him from the direction of his nature, because Satan whispered to him, and Satan was created from a part of what Adam was created from. Adam only forgot and accepted the whispering due to his nature, and the two Hands were directed toward his nature. Yet, despite this, He did not preserve him from what he carried in his clay from his disobedient descendants. So do not wonder at the Jews changing the Torah. For the Torah itself did not change; rather, the change affected their writing of it and their pronunciation of it. Such a thing was attributed to the Speech of God, for He said: <<يُحَرِّفُونَهُ مِنْ بَعْدِ مَا عَقَلُوهُ وَهُمْ يَعْلَمُونَ>> (They distort it after they have understood it, while they know). The Speech of God is intelligible to them, but they manifest in their translation of it something contrary to what is in their hearts and in their scripture revealed to them. For they only distorted it when they copied it from the original, and they kept the original as it was so that the knowledge would remain for them and their scholars. But Adam, despite the two Hands, disobeyed by himself and was not preserved like the Speech of God was preserved. This is more wondrous. The Speech of God was preserved only because it is a Decree (Ḥukm), and the Decree is preserved, and its locus is the scholars who know it. It is not distorted among the scholars, but they distort it for their followers. Adam is not the Decree of God, so preservation is not necessary for him in himself, though preservation is necessary for him in what he conveys of the Decree from his Lord, if he is a Messenger, as is the case for all Messengers. This is a noble science. For God did not place guidance (hudā) in the World that could turn back into blindness (‘amā). He made it clear to the one to whom He delivered it. Blindness is only attributed to the one to whom guidance from his Lord has not reached. And the one who is told, 'This is guidance,' is not said to have received it until he is the one upon whom the guidance was revealed and who attained the knowledge of it. For such a person will never have blindness. No one prefers blindness over guidance except one who is a follower (muqallid) of his own kind in both matters. Blindness agrees with his nature, and guidance contradicts his nature, so he prefers the former over the latter."

I saw in it the science of one who is patient (itta’ada) and relies upon God. This is the fifth type of reliance (Tawakkul), which is His saying in Sūrat al-Muzzammil: <<فَاتَّخِذْهُ وَكِيلًا>> (So take Him as a Trustee).

I saw in it the science of what is attained by inheritance (wirth) and the science of what is attained by acquisition (kasb).

I saw in it the science of the difference between the gratitude of the responsible person (al-mukallaf) and the gratitude of the servant (al-‘abd).

I saw in it the science of the variation of rulings due to the variation of times, for it is impossible for anything to occur in the World except with a temporal arrangement, precedence and subsequence, and differentiation. This is because God showed me His Names (al-Asmā’), and I saw them differentiating due to their sharing in some matters and their distinction in others, despite the sharing. Any Name in which there is no sharing with another Name, there is no differentiation between the essences of those two Names—know this, for it is a precious science.

I saw in it the science of the subjugation of one part of the World over another, and its cause. I saw that it stems from the ruling of the Divine Names in their desire for manifestation, their governance (wilāya), and the jealousy (ghayra) that is upon them. I saw them seeking help from the Names that share with them; thus, they are the helped and the helper. For this reason, Creation came forth upon their form, so among them are the helped and the helper. When the matter occurred thus, He addressed them with the ruling of cooperation, saying: <<وَتَعَاوَنُوا عَلَى الْبِرِّ وَالتَّقْوَى>> (And cooperate in righteousness and piety). Thus, what they were created upon is servitude, for they may cooperate with that same reality <<عَلَى الْإِثْمِ وَالْعُدْوَانِ>> (in sin and aggression).

I saw the science of Compulsion (Jabr). I saw that it is the last point to which excuses terminate, and it is the reason for Creation’s inclination toward Mercy. For God excuses His creation by it concerning what originated from them. Nothing remains of them except natural supplication (al-taḍarru‘ al-ṭabī‘ī). Were it not that the formation of the Hereafter is like the formation of the World—possessing a natural body and a spirit—the request or supplication of the wretched person would not be valid. For if there were no natural matter there, the soul, when ignorant, would have no one to alert it to its ignorance due to its lack of sensation, as it has no sensation except through the natural part, which is the composite body. And its wretchedness is due to ignorance. Thus, the soul, after separation, if it separates while in ignorance, its wretchedness is its ignorance, and it remains in it forever. It is from God’s Mercy upon it that He made this natural composite for it in the World and the Hereafter. Not everyone knows the wisdom of this composite, which no living being is without.

I saw the science of the Return (al-Raj‘a), which is the science of the Resurrection and the gathering of bodies in the Hereafter, and that when a person transitions from the World (Dunya), he will never return to it, but it transitions with him upon his transition. From this abode, some transition to Paradise and some transition to the Fire. The Fire and Paradise encompass the abode of the World and its bliss. For no abode remains except Paradise and the Fire, and the World does not cease to exist after its existence, nor does anything existent cease. It must be in the two abodes or in one of them. Unveiling (Kashf) granted that it is divided between the two abodes. There are prophetic reports concerning this that are sufficient. Some Companions used to say: "O sea, when will you return as fire?"—which is the scalding water (al-ḥamīm) that the people of the Fire drink. And his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, concerning the four rivers, that they are from Paradise, mentioning the Sayhan, the Jayhan, the Nile, and the Euphrates. And: "Between my grave and my pulpit is a garden (rawḍa) from the gardens of Paradise."

And the gatherings of remembrance (majālis al-dhikr), wherever they are, are gardens from the gardens of Paradise. The reports concerning this are numerous. We are not people of imitation (taqlīd), praise be to God; rather, the matter for us is as we believed it from our Lord—we witnessed it directly.

I saw in it the science of the Level (martaba) of the Prophet’s saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "I will boast of your numbers before the nations."

And that this is a matter of honor and glory in its station, so such a thing should not be neglected, for every station has a specific honor that is only achieved through it. Here, a group of Gnostics slipped, as they did not distinguish between the honor of the souls and the honor of the intellects, and that they do not interpenetrate, and that perfection lies in the existence of both honors.

I saw in it the science that man only sees what he was upon, whether he knows it or is ignorant of it. He must witness it and know it in the place where knowledge of it or witnessing it will not benefit him.

I saw in it the science of Interpenetration and Circularity (Al-Dawr): that the Real (al-Haqq) only exists in the form of Creation (al-Khalq) in action, and Creation only exists in it in the form of the Real. This is a circularity that does not lead to the impossibility of occurrence; rather, it is the reality upon which the matter stands.

<<فَإِنَّ اللَّهَ لَا يَمَلُّ حَتَّى تَمَلُّوا>> (Indeed, Allah does not tire until you tire).

This is a ruling of Creation concerning the Real. And He said: <<فَمَنْ يُرِدِ اللَّهُ أَنْ يَهْدِيَهُ يَشْرَحْ صَدْرَهُ لِلْإِسْلَامِ وَمَنْ يُرِدْ أَنْ يُضِلَّهُ يَجْعَلْ صَدْرَهُ ضَيِّقًا حَرَجًا>> (So whoever Allah wants to guide, He expands his breast to Islam; and whoever He wants to misguide, He makes his breast tight and constricted). This is from Him, just as His return and outcome were from us.

I saw in it the science of the station of the Qur’an in relation to the World, for whom it came, with what it came, and to where it returns.

I saw in it the science of Delusion (Talbīs) and that its origin is human haste. If man were patient, reflected, and observed, no matter would be confused for him, but few do that.

I saw in it the science of the Night alone, the Day alone, Time (al-Zamān) alone, the Day (al-Yawm) alone, Eternity (al-Dahr) alone, the Age (al-‘Aṣr) alone, and the Duration (al-Mudda) alone.

I saw in it the science of detail (al-Tafṣīl) in what has appeared.

I saw in it the science of what is incumbent upon man from the ruling of God that the Law (Shar‘) has detailed, from which he cannot be separated.

I saw in it the science of the opposition of the two copies, and that man himself is the book of his Lord.

I saw in it the science of the reason for the necessity of punishment (‘adhāb) in the Hereafter, which is manifest. The hidden knowledge is only in the existence of the cause of the punishment of the World, especially concerning the suckling infant. Do the suckling infant and all animals have a Divine obligation (taklīf ilāhī) through a messenger from among themselves in their essences, which they do not perceive? And when the child grows up and becomes responsible, he does not perceive or remember his obligation during his infancy due to the pains that afflict him, and the same applies to the animal. For He, the Exalted, does not punish initially, but punishes as a recompense (jazā’). Mercy does not necessitate punishment except as a recompense for purification. Were it not for purification, punishment would not occur. This is one of the secrets of knowledge with which God distinguishes whomever He wills of His servants. <<وَلِكُلِّ أُمَّةٍ رَسُولٌ>> (And for every nation is a messenger), and <<وَإِنْ مِنْ أُمَّةٍ إِلَّا خَلَا فِيهَا نَذِيرٌ>> (And there is no nation but that there has passed within it a warner). There is nothing in Existence except that it is a nation (umma) among the nations. God the Exalted said: <<وَمَا مِنْ دَابَّةٍ فِي الْأَرْضِ وَلَا طَائِرٍ يَطِيرُ بِجَنَاحَيْهِ إِلَّا أُمَمٌ أَمْثَالُكُمْ>> (And there is no creature on [or moving within] the earth or bird that flies with its two wings except [that they are] communities like you) in everything. And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said concerning dogs that they are a nation among the nations.

Thus, the Divine Message (al-Risāla al-Ilāhiyya) encompasses all nations, their small and their great. There is no nation except that it is under a Divine address upon the tongue of a warner (nadhīr) sent to it, from it, and within it.

I saw in it the science of the ruling of the expanded, optional obligation (al-wujūb al-muwassa‘ al-mukhayyar), such as the times of prayers and the option in expiations (kaffārāt).

I saw in it the science of the Real being in accordance with the servant’s will (irāda), not opposing it. This attribute is more appropriate for the servant. Just as God commanded His servant and he disobeyed Him, so too did His servant call upon Him, and He did not answer him in what he asked, just as He commanded him and he did not obey Him. Do you not see that when the angels did not disobey the command of God, God answered them in everything they asked for, to the extent that if the servant’s saying of "Amen" in prayer coincides with the angels’ saying of "Amen," he is forgiven?

I saw in it the universality of Divine Giving (al-‘Aṭā’) and that the occurrence of major sins (al-kabā’ir) in the responsible world is from Divine Generosity (al-Karam al-Ilāhī). For a group must undergo substitution (tabdīl), and a major sin is substituted by a major good deed:

> The giving of life to a soul by the killing of a soul,
> In every kind and every genus.

Some people have substitution granted to them through repentance and righteous deeds, and some people have substitution granted to them after the punishment has taken its full due from them. The reason for the execution of the threat (al-wa‘īd) against a group is the ruling of the Divine Will (al-Mashī’a al-Ilāhiyya). When the duration ends, the Will seeks to substitute the punishment they were in with a similar bliss. For the ruling of the Will is stronger than the ruling of the Command (al-Amr). Substitution has occurred by the Command, so it is more deserving of occurrence by the Will (al-Irāda). God concealed this knowledge from some of His servants and revealed it to whomever He willed of His servants. It is part of the science of Wisdom (al-Ḥikma), and whoever is granted it <<فَقَدْ أُوتِيَ خَيْرًا كَثِيرًا>> (has certainly been given much good). That is why the Real, the Exalted, said: <<وَكَانَ اللَّهُ غَفُورًا رَحِيمًا>> (And Allah is ever Forgiving, Merciful)—Forgiving, meaning He conceals; Merciful, meaning by that concealment—after His saying: <<فَأُولَئِكَ يُبَدِّلُ اللَّهُ سَيِّئَاتِهِمْ حَسَنَاتٍ>> (For those, Allah will change their evil deeds into good deeds). And He said concerning the extravagant sinners (al-musrifīn): <<لَا تَقْنَطُوا مِنْ رَحْمَةِ اللَّهِ إِنَّ اللَّهَ يَغْفِرُ الذُّنُوبَ جَمِيعًا إِنَّهُ هُوَ الْغَفُورُ الرَّحِيمُ>> (Do not despair of the Mercy of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful). He brought forth forgiveness and mercy concerning the repentant and the doer of righteous deeds, just as He brought them forth concerning the extravagant sinners who did not repent, forbidding them from despair and emphasizing it with His saying "all" (jamī‘an).

More than this Divine clarification regarding the outcome of His servants being Mercy is what occurs with the habitation of the two abodes, Paradise and Hell, and that each of them has its inhabitants who will not leave it. The giving of God has no preventer (māni‘). The Name "The Preventer" (al-Māni‘) only relates to the fact that the bliss of Zayd is prevented from ‘Amr, just as the bliss of ‘Amr is prevented from Zayd. This is the ruling of the Preventer, not that it prevents the encompassing nature of Mercy.

I saw in it the science of the difference between the differentiation of the inferior ones in the World and their differentiation in the Hereafter.

I saw in it the science of why one who abandons his state abandons it, and its cause.

I saw in it the science that God is the Worshipped (al-Ma‘būd) in every object of worship, behind the veil of the form.

I saw in it the science of gentleness (Rifq) with the World and treating every category with the gentleness appropriate to it.

I saw in it the science that man only reaps the fruit of his own planting, nothing else.

I saw in it the science of the limits (ḥudūd) in dispositions, their measures, and their weights.

I saw in it the science of assuming the Divine Qualities (al-Takhalluq bi-l-Akhlāq al-Ilāhiyya), specifically His being Lord (Rabb).

I saw in it the science of the ruling of the part relative to the whole, even if the part is in the form of the whole.

I saw in it the science of the production of sound knowledge from two false premises, such as: "Every human is a stone," and "Every stone is an animal," therefore, "Every human is an animal." The falsity of the two premises did not necessitate that the conclusion be unsound. The balance of this is not known.

I saw in it the science of the effect of a like upon its like, and by what means it affects it, when neither of them is more worthy than the other or more entitled to the attribution of the effect to it. And the two likes are opposites—so understand.

I saw in it the science of Frivolity/Vainness (‘Abath) and how it can be correct despite His saying, the Exalted: <<وَمَا خَلَقْنَا السَّمَاءَ وَالْأَرْضَ وَمَا بَيْنَهُمَا بَاطِلًا>> (And We did not create the heaven and earth and that between them in vain [bāṭil]). Frivolity is in what is between them. By which perspective is it frivolous, and by which perspective is it not vain? And God’s saying: <<أَفَحَسِبْتُمْ أَنَّمَا خَلَقْنَاكُمْ عَبَثًا>> (Did you think that We created you in vain [‘abathan]?)—He qualified this, but He did not qualify the vain (bāṭil).

I saw the science of the superiority of males over females, which is an accidental (a‘raḍiyya) differentiation, not essential (dhātiyya).

I saw in it the science of the rulings of the impossible (al-muḥāl), the state (al-ḥāl), the place (al-makān), and the one established in it (al-mutamakkin).

I saw in it the science of the veils that prevent Divine influence (al-ta’thīr al-Ilāhī) in the one veiled by them.

I saw in it the science of the sovereignty of Singularity (Aḥadiyya), and that no one remains under its sovereignty. And whether a Theophany (Tajallī) is valid within it or not. The one who affirms Theophany in it—does he mean the singularity of the One (aḥadiyyat al-wāḥid) or the singularity of the totality (aḥadiyyat al-majmū‘)? Likewise, the one who denies Theophany in it—does he mean the singularity of the One or the singularity of the totality?

I saw in it the science of the etiquette of spiritual audition (Samā‘) and refraining from speech during it.

I saw the science of attaching the lower to the higher in the ruling of setting an analogy for it, and who this higher one is, and by what means he is higher.

I saw in it the science of the one compelled to praise someone he previously blamed before the compulsion.

I saw in it the science of the preventing cause that hinders the rational person from traversing the most difficult path and taking the most preferable and rightful course.

I saw in it the science of the ascent and descent of a single person due to the variation of states, and why the one who descended descended, and who caused him to descend, and why the one who ascended ascended, and who caused him to ascend.

I saw in it the science of the states of people in the Isthmus (Barzakh), for the reports concerning it are contradictory. Is the contradiction general or specific? And is the generality and specificity in time or in persons?

I saw in it the science of the benefit of the signs (āyāt) that do not come for the purpose of miracle (i‘jāz). For what purpose did they come?

I saw in it the science of the reason that emboldens the weak person in all respects against the strong person in all respects, despite the weak person’s knowledge that the strong one is capable of destroying him.

I saw in it the science of Iblis’s obedience to his Lord in everything except the prostration to Adam. And why Adam was mentioned as having disobeyed God’s prohibition (<<عَصَى>>), while it was said of Iblis <<أَبَى>> (refused), and it was not said of him that he disobeyed God’s command? Is this an honor that reverts to Adam because he is upon the Form (al-Ṣūra), and Iblis does not have this station? God mentioned concerning Adam that he disobeyed his Lord, thus mentioning the one who disobeyed, but He only mentioned concerning Iblis that he refused (abā), and did not mention that he refused to comply with the command of his Lord. In another verse, it was said: <<لَمْ يَكُنْ مِنَ السَّاجِدِينَ>> (He was not among those who prostrated). In another verse, it was said: <<اسْتَكْبَرَ>> (He was arrogant). In another verse, he said: <<أَأَسْجُدُ لِمَنْ خَلَقْتَ طِينًا>> (Shall I prostrate to one You created from clay?). And in another verse, it was said: <<أَبَى أَنْ يَكُونَ مَعَ السَّاجِدِينَ>> (He refused to be with those who prostrated). Look at what the Real has granted you in these verses and the secrets contained within them.

I saw in it the science of Delusion (Ightirār).

I saw in it the science of who among created beings was favored over Adam, and that his favor was not universal. Thus, the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, informed me in a vision I saw, and thus Abraham the Intimate, peace be upon him, informed our Shaykh Abū Madyan that Adam’s favor was not universal.

I saw in it the science of the Imamate and the Imam.

I saw in it the science that the World (Dunya) is the title (unwān) of the Hereafter and an analogy for it, and that the ruling of what is in it is more complete and perfect in the Hereafter.

I saw in it the science of the reason for which the heart of the person knowledgeable of a thing deviates from what his knowledge dictates, and what its ruling is.

I saw in it the science of God’s custom (Sunna) regarding His servants, which does not change.

I saw in it the science of timing the Conversation with the Real (muḥādathat al-Ḥaqq), which is necessary for the person of Divine care, and the combination of Witnessing (Shuhūd) and Conversation, and what part of the Conversation is intimate talk (musāmara), and that the Real does not refuse intimate talk but refuses Conversation at certain times. This is a Divine address from the servant to God and from God to the servant, and what this knowledge yields for the one who knows it on the Day of Resurrection.

I saw in it the science of the states of the truthful (al-ṣādiqīn) in their movements when entering the Divine Presence (al-Ḥaḍra al-Ilāhiyya) from the World and exiting from it to the World. Among those who were established in this station is Abū Yazīd al-Bisṭāmī.

I saw in it the science of the personification of Non-existence (‘Adam) so that rulings can be applied to it, which are affected by Existence. If it were not so, it would not be intelligible. Its form is the form of the Theophany of the Real (tajallī al-Ḥaqq) in whatever form He appears. Rulings are applied to it according to the ruling applied to that form in which He disclosed Himself, and its ruling necessitates it. From this, everything attributed to Him, the Exalted, that came to us in the Book and the Sunna is attributed, and this does not necessitate anthropomorphism (tashbīh).

I saw in it the science of Divine Medicine (al-Ṭibb al-Ilāhī) for natural bodies, not for character traits, although it may apply to character traits, for the sickness of the soul due to base character traits is greater than the sickness of natural bodies.

I saw in it the science that the actor does not exceed what his nature and temperament necessitate, if he possesses a temperament. If the actor is one who has no temperament, then his action is according to what he is in his Essence (dhāt).

I saw in it the science of the ruling concerning one who is asked about what he knows but replies that he does not know. This becomes knowledge for the questioner that the respondent knows what he was asked about. If he answers with what he knows, as the matter is in itself, and the questioner knows it, then he knows that the respondent does not know what the questioner asked about.

I saw in it the science of cooperation in attaining knowledge: when it is found, does it result in all the knowledge cooperated upon, or does it result in some knowledge but not others?

I saw in it the science of the reason for establishing Divine Laws (Sharā’i‘) and sending Messengers.

I saw in it the science of the reason for controlling the Messengers (al-Taḥakkum ‘alā al-Rusul). Is it praiseworthy or blameworthy, or neither praiseworthy nor blameworthy, or praiseworthy in one station and blameworthy in another?

I saw in it the science of the impediment preventing the simultaneous occurrence of possibilities—meaning those that have occurred. Is that possible or not? And in what context is it possible, and in what context is it not possible? And in what context is it possible, has it occurred or not?

And there is nothing there except substance (jawhar) or accident (‘araḍ), carrier and carried, subsisting by itself and not subsisting by itself. This division includes the body and what is not body. Is the body a collection of accidents and attributes, and the substance likewise, or is it not so?

I saw in it the science of the rank of the number Nine.

I saw in it the science of the opposition of the two adversaries: did what led them to dispute arise from an existent matter (amr wujūdī) or a non-existent matter (‘adamī)?

I saw in it the science of the Real by which Creation is created (al-Ḥaqq al-makhlūq bihi).

I saw in it the science of naming the single Name among the Names with all the Names, as was held by the author of *Khala‘ al-Na‘layn* (The Removal of the Two Sandals), Abū al-Qāsim ibn Qasī, may God have mercy on him.

I saw in it the science of the ranks of praises and their consequences. <<وَاللَّهُ يَقُولُ الْحَقَّ وَهُوَ يَهْدِي السَّبِيلَ>> (And Allah speaks the truth, and He guides to the way).
content.ur:
باب تین سو سڑسٹھ: توکل کے پانچویں مقام کی معرفت میں، جسے محققین میں سے کسی نے بھی اس کے قابل لوگوں کی کمی اور عقلوں کے اس کے ادراک سے قاصر ہونے کی وجہ سے ظاہر نہیں کیا۔

توکل اسباب کو ثابت کرتا ہے *** اور تالوں اور دروازوں کو کھولتا ہے۔
اور اپنے لیے عام خیر و بھلائی کی سخاوت کرتا ہے *** اور دشمنوں اور دوستوں کو قریب لاتا ہے۔
اور کمزور نفس کو نصیحت کرتے ہوئے کہتا ہے *** اپنے معبود کو ایک جان اور دوسرے معبودوں کو چھوڑ دے۔
میں اس کا خلیفہ ہوں اور میں نے اسے توکل کیا ہے *** پس جس نے میرے نقش قدم کی پیروی کی، وہ اس تک پہنچ گیا۔
میں اس کے لیے رحم ہوں اور یہی میرا وسیلہ ہے *** پس وہ نجات پا گیا جو نسبوں کی حفاظت کرتا ہے۔

### [جب وہ رات کے آخری تہائی حصے میں آسمان دنیا پر نزول فرماتا ہے]

اللہ تعالیٰ نے فرمایا: لَيْسَ كَمِثْلِهِ شَيْ‏ءٌ (اس جیسی کوئی چیز نہیں ہے)۔ پس اس نے اپنی ذات کو ایک ایسے وصف سے بیان کیا جو صرف اسی کے لیے سزاوار ہے، اور وہ اس کا یہ قول ہے: وهُوَ مَعَكُمْ أَيْنَ ما كُنْتُمْ (اور وہ تمہارے ساتھ ہے جہاں کہیں بھی تم ہو)۔ پس وہ تعالیٰ ہمارے ساتھ ہے جہاں کہیں بھی ہم ہوں، اس حال میں بھی جب وہ رات کے آخری تہائی حصے میں آسمان دنیا پر نزول فرماتا ہے، اس حال میں بھی جب وہ عرش پر استواء (مستوی) ہے، اس حال میں بھی جب وہ عماء (بادل) میں ہے، اس حال میں بھی جب وہ زمین اور آسمان میں ہے، اس حال میں بھی جب وہ انسان کی شہ رگ (حَبْلِ الْوَرِيدِ) سے بھی زیادہ قریب ہے۔ اور یہ ایسی صفات ہیں جن سے اس کے سوا کسی اور کو متصف نہیں کیا جا سکتا۔ اللہ کسی بندے کو ایک جگہ سے دوسری جگہ اس لیے منتقل نہیں کرتا کہ وہ اسے دیکھے، بلکہ اس لیے کہ وہ اسے اپنی ان نشانیوں (آیات) میں سے دکھائے جو اس سے پوشیدہ تھیں۔

اللہ تعالیٰ نے فرمایا: سُبْحانَ الَّذِي أَسْرى‏ بِعَبْدِهِ لَيْلًا من الْمَسْجِدِ الْحَرامِ إِلَى الْمَسْجِدِ الْأَقْصَى الَّذِي بارَكْنا حَوْلَهُ لِنُرِيَهُ من آياتِنا (پاک ہے وہ ذات جو اپنے بندے کو رات کے وقت مسجد حرام سے مسجد اقصیٰ تک لے گئی جس کے ماحول کو ہم نے برکت دی تاکہ ہم اسے اپنی کچھ نشانیاں دکھائیں)۔ اسی طرح جب اللہ بندے کو اس کے احوال میں منتقل کرتا ہے تاکہ اسے بھی اپنی نشانیاں دکھائے۔ پس اس کا احوال میں منتقل کرنا اس کی مثال ہے جیسے:

نبی اکرم صَلَّى اللهُ عَليهِ وسَلَّم کا یہ فرمان: "میرے لیے زمین سمیٹ دی گئی، پس میں نے اس کے مشرق و مغرب دیکھے، اور میری امت کی بادشاہت وہاں تک پہنچے گی جہاں تک میرے لیے سمیٹا گیا ہے۔"
